question: How do I register a business name in Nigeria?
answer: To register a business name in Nigeria you have to do the following:  Go to icrp.cac.gov.ng  Signup for a public user account and login  Reserve your desired name and wait for the name approval  After the name has been approved, you can then start the registration process by using the availability code attached to the name reservation approval note.

question: How do I resolve duplication of Directors/Proprietors/Partners/Trustees
answer: details? This may occur in applications submitted using the Public User Account. To resolve this, follow the steps below:  Edit your profile information by clicking on “Profile” at the top right corner of the page  Select Edit  Complete all the fields  Save and exit page  Go back to the dashboard  Select delete on the duplicated entry

question: Why do I find it difficult to upload picture, signature or document?
answer: This usually occurs if the format and size of the picture/signature/documents you want to upload are not in the prescribed format. The format for pictures and signatures is jpeg/PNJ while the format for documents is PDF. The maximum size for file upload is 5MB.

question: Why is my payment of filing fee or stamp duty not reflected on the portal,
answer: even though I have been debited by my bank? This may be due to a number of factors. To resolve, log in to the portal and click on the “Check Payment Status” or “Check Status/Pay Stamp Duty” button(s) against the application. In the event that the payment is still not reflected, please contact support@remita.net , copy dogara@systemspec.com  or support@stampduty.gov.ng  or your bank.

question: What do I do if I make a mistake on my reserved name?
answer: You may wait for the name approval to expire after 60 days or you may proceed with the registration in the reserved name and apply for a change of name after registration.

question: Why do I get the error report “Invalid Username or Password” when I want to
answer: log in to my portal? This may occur when using the wrong credential to log in to your portal. To resolve this, use either your e-mail address, phone number or accreditation number submitted while creating the account as the username for login. If you have forgotten your password, click on the “Forgotten Password” button and follow the link sent to your e- mail address to change your password.

question: What should I if CAC asks me to change the approved name for the entity after
answer: I have submitted the application for registration? Where the CAC asks you to change the approved name for the entity after the application has been submitted for registration, you should reserve another name and select ‘Name substitution’ as a reason for the name reservation. If the new name is approved, then login to CRP and click on the ‘resolve query’ on your dashboard.

question: What should I do if my login credential is showing User not authorized when
answer: trying to login to icrp? Please ensure that there is steady internet connection on your device or use different internet browser or clear your browser’s cache. Also, avoid many login attempts with the wrong password or username as the system will lock your account. If the issue persists, lodge a complaint on the Support Center. In addition, you can log in with your email address or accreditation number, or phone number as a substitute for a username.

question: What should I do if CAC asks me to increase my issued share capital?
answer: This happens where the company’s issued share capital is lower than the prescribed issued share capital for the proposed object(s).   You may resolve this by either expunging the specific object(s) or increasing the issued share capital to meet the prescribed minimum issued share capital. Where the issued share capital is increased to meet the prescribed minimum issued share capital, filing fees and stamp duties should be paid on the increase through remita.net and stampduty.gov.ng respectively. After payment, receipts for the payments should be uploaded as “OTHERS” under the upload options.

question: What is the Commission’s Refund Policy?
answer: The following are the Corporate Affairs Commission’s Refund Policy  An application for refund stating clearly the reason for refund.  Such application must carry the name, telephone number, account number and an active email address, for ease of communication with the applicant/beneficiary.  Applicant must attach evidence of payment(s) made (i.e. Remita Retrieval Reference).  Where there are multiple payments in a transaction, all the receipts must be attached to the application.  Where the reason for refund is as a result of the applicant’s fault, a deduction of 5% administrative charge is applicable.  Where refund relates to Pre-incorporation and Post-incorporation applications, payments shall be made to the Payer and Principal respectively.  Application for refund shall be forwarded to audit@cac.gov.ng .

question: How do I rectify the changes in the personal data of director, shareholders,

question: What is the cost of registering a business in Nigeria?
answer: The followings are the cost of registering a business in Nigeria payable to CAC:  Limited Liability Company – About 20,000 Naira Stamp Duty inclusive.  Business Name – 11,000 Naira  Incorporate Trustee (NGO) – About 70,000 Naira

question: What are the different types of business registrations in Nigeria?
answer: The different types of Business Registration in Nigeria are as follows:  Business Name – Small and Micro-businesses: This is the simplest form suitable for sole proprietorships or partnerships where the owner(s) are personally liable for business debts. Registration involves obtaining a business name registration with the CAC.  Private Limited Company (Ltd): This is a popular choice for small to medium sized businesses. It offers limited liability, meaning the owners’ personal assets are protected from business debts.  Public Limited Company (PLC): This structure is for larger businesses that intend to offer shares to the public. It requires more stringent regulations and reporting requirements.  Incorporated Trustees: This is for non-profit organizations, charitable bodies, or religious organizations that wants to operate as a legal entity.  Partnership: This involves two or more individuals agreeing to share in the profit or losses of a business. Partners typically share liability for business debts.  Limited Liability Partnership (LLP): This is a hybrid structure that combines elements of partnership and limited liability companies. It provides limited liability protection to the partners while allowing them to operate as a separate legal entity.

question: What are the documents needed for NGO registration in Nigeria?

question: What is the cost of obtaining a TIN?
answer: Obtaining a Tax Identification Number (TIN) is free of charge and can be done at any FIRS office.

question: Do small businesses need to pay VAT in Nigeria?
answer: Yes, businesses with an annual turnover of ₦25 million and above are required to register for VAT and remit payments to the FIRS. 3. Nigeria Custom Service (NCS)

question: How can I obtain an import license in Nigeria?
answer: To obtain an import license, you must register with the Federal Ministry of Finance, provide company registration details, and comply with Nigerian Customs requirements.

question: What are the import duties and taxes applicable in Nigeria?
answer: Import duties in Nigeria vary based on the type of goods being imported. Common rates include 5%, 10%, and 20%. Additionally, VAT at 7.5% is applied to most imports.

question: How do I track my shipment with NCS?
answer: You can track your shipment by visiting the NCS website and using their tracking tool, or by contacting their customer service for assistance.

question: What is the process for registering for PAYE in Nigeria?
answer: To register for PAYE, employers must register with the FIRS, obtain a TIN, and submit employee details for tax deduction purposes.

question: How often do I need to file VAT returns in Nigeria?
answer: VAT returns must be filed monthly, and payments are due by the 21st day of the following month.

question: What are the penalties for late payment of taxes in Nigeria?
answer: Penalties for late payment of taxes can include fines, interest on the overdue amount, and potential legal action by the FIRS.

question: How do I update my business information with CAC?

question: Can I use my phone to register my business?
answer: Yes, you can use your phone to register your business as long as you have a stable internet connection and access to the required documents in digital format. Also ensure to put your phone on desktop view for a good user experience

question: What internet browser is best for registering my business?
answer: For the best experience when registering your business, it is recommended to use Google Chrome or Mozilla Firefox as they are compatible with most online registration portals.

question: What should I do if I encounter technical issues during the registration process?
answer: If you encounter technical issues during the registration process, try refreshing the page, clearing your browser cache, or using a different browser. If the problem persists, contact customer support for assistance.

question: Can I register a business name that is similar to an existing one?
answer: No, you cannot register a business name that is identical or too similar to an existing registered business name. The CAC will reject names that are likely to cause confusion with existing names.

question: What are the common reasons for name rejection during business registration?
answer: Common reasons for name rejection include:  The name is identical or too similar to an existing registered name.  The name contains prohibited words or phrases.  The name is misleading or implies government affiliation.  The name does not comply with naming conventions set by the CAC.

question: How do I check the status of my business registration application?
answer: You can check the status of your business registration application by logging into your account on the CAC portal and navigating to the dashboard where you can view the status of your application.

question: What should I do if my business registration application is rejected?
answer: If your business registration application is rejected, review the rejection reasons provided by the CAC, make the necessary corrections, and resubmit your application. You may also seek assistance from a CAC registration expert if needed.

question: Can I change my business name after registration?
answer: Yes, you can change your business name after registration by applying for a name change through the CAC. This process may involve additional fees and documentation.

question: What are the benefits of registering a business in Nigeria?
answer: Benefits of registering a business in Nigeria include:  Legal recognition and protection of the business name.  Ability to open a corporate bank account.  Access to government grants and incentives.  Enhanced credibility with customers and suppliers.  Limited liability protection for business owners (in the case of companies).

answer: A business name is a simpler form of registration suitable for sole proprietorships or partnerships, while a company (Ltd or PLC) is a more complex structure that offers limited liability protection and is suitable for larger businesses.

question: What do I do if I fall into a commercial dispute with a Nigerian business?
answer: The Nigerian Export Promotion Council is not able to provide assistance in relation to commercial disputes with Nigerian companies. However, you can seek legal assistance with the help of the embassy and high commission of your country in Nigeria.

question: How can I get help with sourcing from Nigeria?
answer: You can get help with sourcing from Nigeria by contacting the Nigerian Export Promotion Council (NEPC) through their official website, email (enquiries@nepc.gov.ng), or phone (+234 802 871 6801).

question: What are some popular products to source from Nigeria?
answer: Popular products to source from Nigeria include agricultural products (such as cocoa, sesame seeds, and cashew nuts), textiles and garments, leather goods, and handicrafts.

question: What is the process for importing goods from Nigeria?
answer: The process for importing goods from Nigeria typically involves identifying a reputable supplier, negotiating terms, arranging for shipping and logistics, and complying with customs regulations in both Nigeria and the destination country.

question: What are the payment methods accepted by Nigerian suppliers?
answer: Nigerian suppliers typically accept various payment methods, including bank transfers, letters of credit, and online payment platforms. It is important to discuss and agree on the payment method with the supplier before finalizing any transactions.

question: What are the shipping options available for importing goods from Nigeria?
answer: Shipping options for importing goods from Nigeria include sea freight, air freight, and courier services. The choice of shipping method will depend on factors such as the type of goods, budget, and delivery timeline.

question: What are the customs regulations for importing goods from Nigeria?
answer: Customs regulations for importing goods from Nigeria vary by country. It is important to research and understand the specific requirements, duties, and taxes applicable in the destination country before importing goods.

question: How can I ensure the quality of products sourced from Nigeria?
answer: To ensure the quality of products sourced from Nigeria, it is advisable to conduct due diligence on suppliers, request product samples, and consider third-party inspections or certifications.

question: What support services does NEPC offer to international buyers?
answer: NEPC offers various support services to international buyers, including assistance with supplier identification, market information, trade facilitation, and export promotion activities.
